The dungeon run will be the real proving ground, revealing precisely which spells I need to prioritize to enhance my capabilities.&quot;</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: center;"><a href="https://oceanofpdf.com/">OceanofPDF.com</a></p><h1 style="padding-top: 2pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: center;"><a name="bookmark17">&zwnj;</a>Chapter 8<a name="bookmark18">&zwnj;</a></h1><p style="padding-top: 21pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">Robert pushed open his office door, the familiar squeak of the hinges a counterpoint to the sudden silence within the room. He stretched, feeling</p><p style="padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">the knots in his back loosen, the worn carpet a familiar softness beneath his feet as he made his way to the kitchen. Sara sat at the table, a half-eaten sandwich in hand, her gaze fixed on some papers spread out before her. &quot;Hey,&quot; he said, leaning against the doorframe, a playful grin on his face. &quot;What&#39;s that? A culinary masterpiece in progress?&quot;</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">Sara looked up, startled, then a responding smirk played on her lips. &quot;Just a humble ham sandwich,&quot; she replied, her eyes twinkling with amusement.</p><p style="padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">&quot;Want one? I made extra, knowing your appetite, you&#39;re always hungry after being in that office for hours.&quot; &quot;You know me too well,&quot; Robert grinned, pulling up a chair and accepting the offered plate. &quot;Don&#39;t mind if I do. Been cooped up in there for too long, staring at that screen. Feels good to stretch my legs.&quot;</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">As Sara went to grab his sandwich, she casually asked, &quot;So, any earth- shattering revelations in your magical man cave today?&quot; Robert&#39;s eyes lit up, a spark of excitement igniting within them. &quot;Actually, yeah,&quot; he said, leaning forward conspiratorially. &quot;This System thing? It&#39;s for real. And guess what? Your husband&#39;s officially a wizard, spells and all.&quot; He struck a playful, over-the-top pose, puffing out his chest and waving his hands dramatically.</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">Sara rolled her eyes, but couldn&#39;t suppress a chuckle. &quot;Right, Merlin,&quot; she said, shaking her head. &quot;I&#39;ll believe it when I see it. Anyway, here&#39;s your sandwich. Don&#39;t choke on your excitement.&quot; She set the plate in front of him with a playful thud. &quot;Prepare to be amazed,&quot; he declared through a mouthful of ham and cheese, gesturing with the other half of his sandwich. &quot;This System is ancient, by the way, and surprisingly well-organized. It even has safeguards for kids. It&#39;s like a whole world in there.&quot;</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">&quot;Oh?&quot; Sara leaned forward, her initial skepticism giving way to genuine intrigue. &quot;Safeguards, you say? What kind?&quot; Robert, now fully engaged in</p><p style="padding-top: 3pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">explaining the intricacies of the System, continued, &quot;Yeah, it restricts information based on age. Little kids, they only see their name, age, and race. Nothing else. More information gets unlocked as they get older, bit by bit, but they can&#39;t change their profile or learn skills until they&#39;re fifteen. It&#39;s like a built-in safety net.&quot;</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">&quot;Fifteen seems young to be making those kinds of choices,&quot; Sara frowned, her brow furrowed in thought. &quot;That&#39;s a lot of responsibility for a teenager.&quot; &quot;Maybe,&quot; Robert conceded, &quot;but I guess that&#39;s when they figure you&#39;re old enough to start taking responsibility for your own life, to start shaping your own destiny. It&#39;s like they&#39;re saying, &#39;Okay, kid, you&#39;ve got the basics, now</p><p style="padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">show us what you can do.&#39;&quot;</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">&quot;I guess so,&quot; Sara said, still looking thoughtful. Then, her expression shifted, becoming playful once more. &quot;So, Mr. Wizard,&quot; she teased, &quot;show me some magic. Harry Potter would be so proud of his competition.&quot; &quot;No wand needed,&quot; Robert chuckled, a grin spreading across his face. He pulled up his spell sheet, looking it over he continued. &quot;I&#39;ve Got some offensive spells, some defensive ones, and even a few healing spells. It&#39;s like a whole arsenal at my fingertips.&quot;</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">&quot;Healing, huh?&quot; Sara&#39;s eyes lit up, and she pointed to a small, angry-looking cut on her leg. &quot;My razor got me this morning. Work your magic, Merlin.</p><p style="padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">Let&#39;s see what you can do.&quot; Robert focused, concentrating on the words of the healing spell, a warmth spreading through his hand as he did. A soft, white light emanated from his palm as he touched her leg, the glow gentle yet powerful. It enveloped the cut, then faded, leaving behind smooth, unbroken skin.</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">There was no trace of the injury, as if it had never existed. &quot;Wow,&quot; Sara breathed, running a finger over her leg in disbelief. &quot;That&#39;s... incredible. It&#39;s like it was never even there.&quot; She playfully added, &quot;And and that had better be the only leg you&#39;ve touched in a while,&quot; Robert teased back, but the lighthearted moment quickly evaporated, replaced by a sudden, heavy silence.</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">&quot;It&#39;s real, then,&quot; Sara said, her voice hushed, almost a whisper. &quot;The System, the magic... all of it. It&#39;s not just some game or some story. It&#39;s actually</p><p style="padding-top: 3pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">real.&quot; &quot;Yeah,&quot; Robert replied, a knot forming in his stomach, the weight of their new reality settling upon him. &quot;It&#39;s real. And it changes everything.&quot;</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">A heavy silence descended, the only sound the gentle hum of the</p><p style="padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">refrigerator in the corner. Sara broke the stillness, her voice laced with worry. &quot;Six months, Robert. That&#39;s not a lot of time. What are we going to do? How are we going to prepare for something like this?&quot; &quot;We&#39;ll figure it out,&quot; he said, trying to sound more confident than he felt, reaching for her hand across the table. &quot;Maybe I can use this healing thing, make some extra money on the side. Every little bit helps, right?&quot;</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">Sara managed a weak smile. &quot;Not sure there&#39;s a huge market for fixing shaving nicks,&quot; she said, attempting to lighten the mood, but her concern was evident. &quot;This is just Tier 1,&quot; Robert pointed out, trying to find a silver lining. &quot;Imagine what a Tier 4 healing spell could do. Maybe I could help people with real problems, serious injuries.&quot;</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">&quot;Could you... could you bring people back from the dead?&quot; Sara&#39;s eyes were wide with a mixture of hope and fear, the question hanging in the air between them. &quot;I don&#39;t know,&quot; Robert admitted, a shiver running down his</p><p style="padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">spine at the thought. &quot;And honestly, I&#39;m not sure I want that kind of power. That&#39;s a heavy burden to bear.&quot;</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">&quot;So, how are we going to tell the kids?&quot; Sara asked, shifting the subject, her voice filled with a mother&#39;s concern. &quot;Straight up,&quot; Robert decided, after a moment of contemplation. &quot;We sit them down, all together, show them the proof. No point in sugarcoating it, pretending it&#39;s something it&#39;s not. They&#39;re smart kids, they deserve the truth.&quot; &quot;You&#39;re right,&quot; Sara agreed, nodding slowly. &quot;They need to know. It&#39;s their future, too.&quot;</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">She paused, her gaze drifting towards the window. &quot;And when are you planning your first dungeon dive, your first foray into this new world?&quot; &quot;Two days,&quot; Robert answered, his mind already racing, planning, strategizing. &quot;Gives me time to practice these spells, maybe learn a light</p><p style="padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">spell  dungeon delving in the dark doesn&#39;t sound fun or safe  and figure out what gear I need. I need to be prepared.&quot;</p><p style="padding-top: 3pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">&quot;Flashlights probably aren&#39;t practical,&quot; Sara mused, thinking aloud. &quot;You&#39;ll need something more reliable, something that won&#39;t run out of batteries.</p><p style="padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">How long do you think you&#39;ll be gone on this first trip?&quot; &quot;Hard to say,&quot; Robert said, rubbing his chin thoughtfully. &quot;But it&#39;s a beginner level, so hopefully just a few hours. I don&#39;t want to push my luck on the first try. I also want to check out the System shop. See what I can buy, what kind of gear they offer.&quot;</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">&quot;Take notes,&quot; Sara suggested, her mind already working on the logistics. &quot;That&#39;s probably where you&#39;ll get most of your equipment. Not like you can walk into a sporting goods store and buy a suit of armor these days.&quot; &quot;Good point,&quot; Robert agreed. &quot;And I&#39;ll get rewards and loot in the dungeon, they say. Thank goodness for that personal inventory space. Imagine having to carry everything around manually.&quot;</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">&quot;Bring something back for the kids,&quot; Sara said, a spark of excitement momentarily flickering in her voice. &quot;They&#39;ll be fascinated. They might not understand the danger, not fully, but loot and adventure? That they&#39;ll get.</p><p style="padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">They&#39;re kids, after all.&quot; &quot;If I find a rat, I&#39;ll bring them a tail,&quot; Robert joked, trying to inject some levity into the increasingly serious conversation.</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">&quot;Please, no,&quot; Sara said firmly, a mock shudder running through her. &quot;I was thinking more along the lines of pictures and videos. Show them what it&#39;s like, if your phone works in there. Let them see this new world through</p><p style="padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">your eyes.&quot; &quot;I&#39;ll try,&quot; Robert said, a faraway look in his eyes. &quot;I didn&#39;t even think to ask if technology works in the dungeon. It&#39;s a whole different set of rules, isn&#39;t it?&quot;</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: justify;">&quot;Well, the whole thing&#39;s run by an AI, so I&#39;m guessing tech is on the table,&quot; Sara pointed out. &quot;It&#39;s all so high-tech, even if it&#39;s based on magic. Wonder what you can take with you when you leave, when you have to go to that</p><p style="padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: justify;">other world.&quot; &quot;Probably nothing that really matters in the grand scheme of things,&quot; Sara said, her voice tinged with sadness, the reality of his eventual departure crashing down on her once more.</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: justify;">Robert reached out and took her hand, his fingers intertwining with hers. &quot;Hey,&quot; he said softly, &quot;I know this is scary. I don&#39;t want to go. I don&#39;t want</p><p style="padding-top: 3pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">to leave you and the kids. But if I have to, I&#39;m going to make the most of it. For you, for the kids, for our future. I&#39;ll become the strongest I can be.&quot;</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">&quot;I know,&quot; Sara whispered, squeezing his hand, her eyes shining with unshed tears. &quot;You always do. You always find a way.&quot; She glanced at the clock on the wall, a sudden urgency in her voice. &quot;John will be home soon, then Richard and Stacey. Time to face the music, time to tell them everything.&quot;</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">&quot;Yeah,&quot; Robert said, his stomach churning with a mixture of apprehension and determination. &quot;Wonder how they&#39;ll take it, how they&#39;ll react to all of this.&quot; &quot;John will be stoic, as always,&quot; Sara predicted with a sigh, a small, knowing smile on her face. &quot;William will worry, he always does, our little worrier. And Stacey, well, Stacey will probably freak out. But we&#39;ll get through it. Together. We always do.&quot;</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: center;"><a href="https://oceanofpdf.com/">OceanofPDF.com</a></p><h1 style="padding-top: 3pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: center;"><a name="bookmark19">&zwnj;</a>Chapter 9<a name="bookmark20">&zwnj;</a></h1><p style="padding-top: 21pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">After wrapping things up at work, I headed back to my office, excited to get back to my spellbook. I figured I had some time before the kids got home, so I wanted to make sure I had a good mix of spells ready to go, ideally</p><p style="padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">some that I could level up soon.</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">I&#39;d already nailed down spells from five of the magic schools, but I still needed to find something useful from Creation, Light, Enchantment, and Time. I started with Light and quickly found a pretty handy one: &#39;Floating Mage Light.&#39; It&#39;s a basic spell, but it&#39;ll be super useful for lighting up the dungeon when we explore. Next, I checked out Time magic. There weren&#39;t a ton of options, but I did find &#39;A Gentle Tick of Time,&#39; which can subtly slow things down a bit. Finally, I landed on &#39;Minor Mending&#39; in the Creation school  it&#39;ll let me fix small tears and cracks in stuff. I was just about to start looking at Enchantment spells when John got home, so my research</p><p style="padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">time was cut short.</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">Sara came into the office, looking curious. &quot;Should we fill John in now, or wait for everyone?&quot; she asked. Robert considered this for a moment. &quot;Let&#39;s give him a quick rundown,&quot; he suggested. &quot;It&#39;ll be less of a shock, and we can use it as practice for when we tell everyone else.&quot; Sara agreed, &quot;Sounds good. We&#39;ll give him the overview now and the deep dive later.&quot; A few minutes later, they heard the front door  John was home. He poked his head into the office, &quot;Hey, what&#39;s going on?&quot;</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">Sara smiled at him. &quot;Hey sweetie, come on in. Your dad and I need to talk to you about something,&quot; she said. Immediately, John got defensive. &quot;Okay, whatever it is, I swear I didn&#39;t do it,&quot; he said quickly. Sara laughed a little. &quot;Don&#39;t worry, you&#39;re not in trouble. Actually, in this case, I&#39;m the supposed one doing it. Or, I guess the one it&#39;s being done too,&quot; she clarified. John looked totally puzzled. &quot;Wait, what&#39;s happening?&quot; he asked.</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">Robert decided to take the lead. &quot;You know how you&#39;re always playing those video games and watching those fantasy shows?&quot; he started. John,</p><p style="padding-top: 3pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">still confused, just replied, &quot;Yeah... so?&quot; Robert continued, &quot;Well, that&#39;s actually going to make this a lot easier to explain. This morning, I had a</p><p style="padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">visitor.&quot; John raised his eyebrows. &quot;What kind of visitor?&quot; he asked. Robert took a deep breath. &quot;The kind that gives out status screens, apparently,&quot; he said, trying to sound serious. John was utterly bewildered. &quot;Status screens? What are you even talking about?&quot; he asked. &quot;I&#39;m talking about these kinds of status screens,&quot; Robert said, and with that, he pulled up his own status screen for John to see.</p><p at the screen. &quot;Whoa, what the hell is that thing? And how are you already Level 4?&quot; he asked, completely baffled. Robert chuckled slightly. &quot;Okay, first off, watch your mouth. Second, I knocked out a couple of simple &#39;quests,&#39; apparently.&quot; Robert then showed him a message</p><p style="padding-top: 3pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">from the System Log, pointing out the six-month deadline. John&#39;s face went white, and he practically leaped out of his chair.</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">&quot;Wait, hold on  you&#39;re leaving? In six months? And never coming back?!&quot; he exclaimed, his voice rising. &quot;Whoa, calm down, son,&quot; Robert said, trying to keep his voice level. &quot;Yes, I am leaving. I know it sucks, and believe me, I wish it were different, but I can&#39;t change it. This... being, whatever it was, that gave me this whole &#39;opportunity&#39; didn&#39;t exactly give me a choice.&quot;</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">&quot;That&#39;s bull!&quot; John yelled, his voice filled with a mix of anger and fear.</p><p style="padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">&quot;There has to be a way to stop it!&quot; Robert shook his head sadly. &quot;We can&#39;t, son,&quot; he repeated. &quot;We&#39;ve already looked into it. The System, or whatever you want to call this thing, has already put a lot into this, into me, and it&#39;s not backing down.&quot; John&#39;s voice was desperate now. &quot;But what about us? Couldn&#39;t the System just take all of us?&quot; he asked. &quot;We asked about that, too,&quot; Robert said, shaking his head again. &quot;It seems like only people directly connected to the System can go, and it&#39;s not willing to take on more people right now. Besides, I wouldn&#39;t, I would never, ask you or your siblings, or your mom, to just drop everything for me, your lives.&quot;</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">John slammed his fist down on the table in frustration. &quot;It&#39;s not about dropping everything, Dad! It&#39;s about staying together, as a family!&quot; Robert sighed, feeling the weight of the situation. &quot;What about your grandparents? Your cousins? All your friends here? What about college? You&#39;ve always dreamed of working at SpaceX,&quot; he reminded him. John slumped back down, defeated.</p><p style="padding-top: 10pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">&quot;It&#39;s not fair,&quot; he mumbled, his voice thick with emotion. &quot;You&#39;re supposed to be there to see the first launch of a rocket I designed.&quot; Robert&#39;s voice was soft. &quot;I know, son. I know, and I&#39;m so sorry. But I can still help you, and maybe, just maybe, I can still be a part of your future, even if I&#39;m not there in person.&quot; John was interested.</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">&quot;How? What do you mean?&quot; John asked, a flicker of curiosity in his eyes. &quot;Skills, son. It&#39;s all about the skills,&quot; Robert replied, bringing up his skill list. &quot;Take a look at this.&quot; John&#39;s eyes scanned the list, widening again. &quot;Whoa, seriously? You can actually do magic? That&#39;s so not fair!&quot; he exclaimed, a touch of playful jealousy creeping into his voice. Robert</p><p style="padding-top: 3pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">smiled. &quot;Well, here&#39;s the thing: I can unlock even more skills, and I can unlock them at Tier 4, which is way beyond normal human ability.&quot; John, still processing, asked, &quot;Okay, but what does that actually mean?</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">How do these skills even work?&quot; &quot;Basically,&quot; Robert explained, &quot;skills give you the knowledge and ability to do things. Like, I have Leatherworking</p><p style="padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">now. When I got that skill, I suddenly knew the basics of working with</p><p style="padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">leather. I didn&#39;t know how to make, like, a specific fancy wallet until I used a skill book, but I understood the fundamentals.&quot;</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">&quot;So,&quot; John said, putting the pieces together, &quot;if you unlocked Blacksmithing, you wouldn&#39;t automatically know how to forge a specific Japanese katana, but you&#39;d understand the general process of making</p><p style="padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">swords?&quot; &quot;Exactly,&quot; Robert confirmed. &quot;And I also have this Teaching skill.</p><p style="padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">It&#39;s pretty basic right now, but if I can get it to Tier 3, I can pass on the knowledge of a skill to someone else, up to Tier 1 Level 10.&quot;</p><p class="s7" style="padding-top: 14pt;padding-left: 34pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">I should interject here and let you know that while you can teach a non-system user, you cannot go above Tier 1 Level 3 with them. Also, you can not teach them more than 1 skill every few weeks, without a core their mind needs a lot of time to recover.</p><p style="padding-top: 15pt;padding-left: 5pt;text-indent: 0pt;text-align: left;">&quot;Hal said that as a non-system user, I can only teach you skills up to Tier 1 Level 3, and I can only teach you 1 skill every few weeks to allow your mind to recover for the download, or whatever it is,&quot; Robert said. &quot;So, what were you thinking of teaching me?&quot; John asked, curious. &quot;This,&quot; Robert said, pulling up a sorted list of available skills.</p><p
